section.name: Part Based
section.p: Open-source solutions are inheriently risky. Communities arise and dissapear with a disconserting frequency. Even commmunities with a strong user community can find themselves abandoned based on little more than policital whims. In comparimon - the commercial model provides a substantially higher degree of longevity largely due to the organizational and control structures in place. In recognition of these risks the Metro platform has introduced a part-management infrastructure aimed directly at risk reduction. When building and deploying a component on platform version X - you don't want to be left out to dry when the community switches to version Y. A solution to this issue is addressed though a part management archictecture that assures interoperability with a series of low-level part APIs. Metro deals with this issue though the separation of low-level component APIs from the APIs dealing with component control. Componets depoyment infomation published under the part data type is tagged relative to the controller implementation. Controllers are in-turn obliged to consolt and potentally delegate runtime concerns to a controller version (and implementatuion) asserted withing a part description. At then end of the day this means that a componet can assert the envoronment within which it is fullly functional - AND - that the components can work and interoperate with components built and deployed with controllers with dramatically different deployment and runtime assumptions.
